controllerTest.py
Go to the documentation of this file.
1 #!/usr/bin/env python3
2 
3 """ This class performs automated controller model testing using the Gym environment and physics simulation. """
4 
5 import copy
6 import os
7 import json
8 
9 import numpy as np
10 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
11 
12 class controllerTest:
13  """!@brief Class implementing automated performance testing of a trained controller model
14 
15  This class implements automated testing of model performance using a provided model and environment.
16  The tests are performed directly in the existing Bullet instance through the gym_jointcontrol environment.
17  Member functions of the jointcontrol environment are accessed as part of the GymEnv instance (using env.env.* instead of env.*).
18  """
19  def __init__(self, env, model, modelname, freqs=[1, 5, 10, 20, 50]) -> None:
20  """
21  Class constructor
22 
23  Params:
24  - env: gym_jointcontrol environment instance used for testing
25  - model: RL model, that uses model.predict(obs) to determine agent actions
26  - modelname: String describing the model, name will be used as the name of the generated results folder
27  """
28 
30  episodeRewards = []
31  obs = env.reset()
32  done = False
33  # Loop until episode is done
34  while not done:
35  # While we are not done, we store final observation, since presumably it represents optimal controller params
36  finalObs = obs
37  action, _ = model.predict(obs)
38  obs, reward, done, _ = env.step(action)
39  episodeRewards.append(reward)
40  #
41  print("Testepisode done. Resulting params are {}".format(finalObs))
42 
44  obs = env.reset()
45  env.env.currentParams = finalObs
46  # Run episode without changing params
47  env.step(None)
48  stepTrajectory = copy.deepcopy(env.env.latestTrajectory)
49  stepControlSignal = copy.deepcopy(env.env.controlSignal)
50  #
51 
53  config = {
54  "lowerSignal": 0,
55  "higherSignal": -1.57,
56  "pulseLength": 0,
57  "numPulses": 2,
58  "maxSteps": 40
59  }
60  # Define tested frequencies and iterate over them
61  #freqs = [ i+1 for i in range(minFreq-1, maxFreq) ]
62  squareTrajectories = []
63  # The lowest frequency (and therefore longest) wave is used as a reference for signal length
64  refLen = int(round((1/freqs[0])/env.env.ts))
65  numPulses = config["numPulses"]
66  for freq in freqs:
67  # Set pulse length based on frequency
68  config["pulseLength"] = int(round((1/freq)/env.env.ts))
69  # Set number of pulses, in order for responses to be equally long
70  config["numPulses"] = int(round(refLen/config["pulseLength"]))*numPulses
71  # Reset env in square mode
72  env.env.reset(episodeType='square', config=config)
73  # Set testing params and perform step
74  env.env.currentParams = finalObs
75  print(config)
76  env.step(None)
77  # Store resulting trajectories
78  squareTrajectories.append(env.env.latestTrajectory)
79  #
80  # Generate dict including all test results and store as class member
81  # modelname -> name of model
82  # ts -> time discretisation
83  # finalObs -> assumed ideal params after final step in episode
84  # episodeRewards -> reward of each step in performed episode
85  # stepTrajectory -> resulting trajectory from step response
86  # freqResponseFrequencies -> frequencies of input square waves for frequency response
87  # freqResponseTrajectories -> resulting trajectories from square input wave tests
88  self.testResults = {
89  "modelname": modelname,
90  "ts": env.env.ts,
91  "finalObs": finalObs,
92  "episodeRewards": episodeRewards,
93  "stepControlSignal": stepControlSignal,
94  "stepTrajectory": stepTrajectory,
95  "freqResponseFrequencies": freqs,
96  "freqResponseTrajectories": squareTrajectories
97  }
98  #
99  def removeArraysFromTestResults(self):
100  """
101  Serialises test results in order to save them as json format.
102 
103  This method is required, since json cannot serialise dicts containing numpy arrays.
104  """
105  data = copy.deepcopy(self.testResults)
106  #
107  for key in data:
108  if isinstance(data[key], np.ndarray):
109  data[key] = data[key].tolist()
110  #
111  return data
112  #
113  def plotResults(self, gui=False, outpath=None):
114  """
115  Plots test results stored in self.testResults
116 
117  Params:
118  - gui: If True, a testreport will be plotted using matplotlib.
119  - outpath: If set, the testreport and raw test data will be saved at the path's location.
120  The report is saved as a pdf, while the data is stored in json format.
121  """
122  # Create Matplotlib figure and set title
123  fig, axs = plt.subplots(3, 1, constrained_layout=True, gridspec_kw={'height_ratios': [1, 1, 2]})
124  fig.suptitle("Testreport for {}".format(self.testResults["modelname"]))
125  #
126  # Cumulative reward over episode
127  axs[0].plot(
128  self.testResults["episodeRewards"]
129  )
130  axs[0].set_xlabel("Episode")
131  axs[0].set_ylabel("Return per Episode")
132  axs[0].set_title("Step Response Episode Reward")
133  #
134  # Resulting trajectory and control signal of step response
135  axs[1].plot (
136  np.arange(len(self.testResults["stepControlSignal"]))*self.testResults["ts"],
137  self.testResults["stepControlSignal"],
138  label = "Control Signal",
139  linestyle=":"
140  )
141  axs[1].plot (
142  np.arange(len(self.testResults["stepTrajectory"]))*self.testResults["ts"],
143  self.testResults["stepTrajectory"],
144  label = "Resulting Position"
145  )
146  axs[1].legend()
147  axs[1].set_xlabel("Time [s]")
148  axs[1].set_ylabel("Joint Position [rad]")
149  axs[1].set_title("Resulting Step Trajectory")
150  #
151  # Plot frequency response curves
152  # Each fraquency is coloured and labelled in order to plot them all in the same plot
153  # One more colour than required is generated and dropped due to the first entry being barely visible on the sequential colour maps
154  colours = plt.cm.Blues(np.linspace( 0, 1, len(self.testResults["freqResponseFrequencies"])+1 ))
155  colours = colours[1:]
156  labels = [ "{} Hz".format(freq) for freq in self.testResults["freqResponseFrequencies"] ]
157  for trajectory, colour, label in zip(
158  self.testResults["freqResponseTrajectories"],
159  colours,
160  labels
161  ):
162  axs[2].plot(
163  self.testResults["ts"]*np.arange(len(trajectory)),
164  trajectory,
165  label = label,
166  color = colour
167  )
168  axs[2].legend()
169  axs[2].set_xlabel("Time [s]")
170  axs[2].set_ylabel("Average Joint Position [rad]")
171  axs[2].set_title("Square Control Signal Frequency Response")
172  #
173  # Increase figure size for a cleaner presentation
174  size = fig.get_size_inches()
175  fig.set_size_inches(size[0]*1.4, size[1]*2)
176  # If outpath is set, create a directory in the path containing the report and raw test data
177  if outpath != None:
178  outpath = "{}/{}".format(outpath, self.testResults["modelname"])
179  os.system( "mkdir {}".format(outpath) )
180  plt.savefig(
181  "{}/{}.pdf".format(outpath, self.testResults["modelname"])
182  )
183  with open( "{}/{}.json".format(outpath, self.testResults["modelname"]), 'w' ) as outfile:
184  json.dump(
185  self.removeArraysFromTestResults(),
186  outfile)
187  # If GUI var is set, visualise the report
188  if gui: plt.show()
189 
190 #TODO: expand to allow for testing of multiple testepisodes
